facts.text: Petitions Nos. 50, 145, 149, 150, 188, 243, 261, 266 of 1955 and 205 of 1956 filed under Article 32 by land proprietors in Rajasthan

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 50, 145, 149, 150, 188, 243, 261, 266 and 362 of 1955 and 205 of 1956. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitions challenge vires of Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949, notifications dated June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953, and Amendment Act No. X of 1954

anchor.surface_text: These are petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by proprietors of lands in the State of Rajasthan, challenging the vires of The Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance, 1949, Ordinance No. IX of 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Ordinance, of notifications dated June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953, issued thereunder and of the Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954.

facts.text: Rajputana consisted of 18 principalities claiming sovereign status under British rule

anchor.surface_text: When the British were the Rulers of this Country, Rajputana, as the State was then known, consisted of 18 principalities claiming sovereign status. After independence, a movement was set afoot for the integration of all the principalities into a single State,

facts.text: Integration of principalities into United State of Rajasthan completed on May 5, 1949

anchor.surface_text: and the process was completed on May 5, 1949, when all of them became merged in a Union called the United State of Rajasthan. The constitution of the State was settled in a Covenant, to which all the Rulers agreed. Under Art 11 of the Covenant, the States agreed to unite and integrate their territories in one State with a common executive, legislature and judiciary by the name of the United State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan constituted on March 29, 1952

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan was constituted and came into being on March 29, 1952, and until then, it was the Rajpramukh in whom the Legislative authority of the State was vested.

facts.text: Rajpramukh promulgated Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949 on June 21, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1949, the Rajpramukh promulgated the impugned legislation, the Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949. The preamble to the Ordinance runs as follows Whereas with a view to putting a check on the growing tendency of landholders to eject or dispossess tenants from their holdings,

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued notification on June 14, 1951 extending Ordinance No. IX of 1949 for two years from June 21, 1951

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power conferred by this section, the Rajpramukh issued a notification on June 14, 1951, providing that Ordinance No. IX of 1949 shall remain in force for a further period of two years with effect from June 21, 1951.

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued notification on June 20, 1953 extending Ordinance for one year from June 21, 1953

anchor.surface_text: On June 20, 1953, he issued a further notification providing that the said Ordinance shall remain in force for a term of one year with effect from June 21, 1953. Doubts would appear to have been expressed about the validity of the notification, dated June 20, 1953,

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued Ordinance No. III of 1954 on February 15, 1954 under Art. 238 substituting s.3 for five years operation

anchor.surface_text: To resolve the doubt, the Rajpramukh issued on February 15, 1954, an Ordinance under Art. 238 of the Constitution, No. III of 1954, substituting for s. 3 the following It shall come into force at once and shall remain in force for a period of five years That would have given operation to Ordinance No. IX of 1949 up to June 21, 1954.

facts.text: Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954 came into force on April 17, 1954 re-enacting s.3 for seven years

anchor.surface_text: Then the Legislature of the State repealed Ordinance No. III of 1954, and enacted the Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954, and that came into force on April 17, 1954. Under this Act, s. 3 of Ordinance No. IX of 1949 was re-enacted as follows It shall come into force at once and shall remain in force for a period of seven years.

facts.text: Rajasthan Tenancy Act No. III of 1955 came into force on October 15, 1955

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on October 15, 1955, a new enactment, the Rajasthan Tenancy Act No. III of 1955, came into force, and the relationship between landlords and tenants is now governed by this Act.

facts.text: Petitions by tenants under Ordinance No. IX of 1949 still undisposed due to stay orders by petitioners

anchor.surface_text: But as a large number of petitions filed by the tenants under Ordinance No. IX of 1949 are still undisposed of by reason of stay orders obtained by the petitioners herein, it is necessary for the purpose of granting relief to them on these petitions,

facts.text: Petitioners contend notifications of June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953 bad as s.3 constitutes delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for petitioners urged the following contentions in support of the petitions The notifications dated June 14, 1951, and June 20, 1953, are bad, as s. 3 of the Ordinance under which they were issued is ultra vires, as constituting delegation of legislative power.

facts.text: Petitioners contend notification dated June 20, 1953 bad because Rajasthan Legislature constituted on March 29, 1952 ending Rajpramukh's authority under Art. 385

anchor.surface_text: The notification dated June 20,1953, is further bad, because the Legislature of Rajasthan had been constituted on March 29, 1952, and the authority of the Rajpramukh to legislate conferred by Art. 385 of the Constitution had, on that date, come to an end.

facts.text: Petitioners contend Act No. X of 1954 bad as it extends life of expired Ordinance No. IX of 1949

anchor.surface_text: Act No. X of 1954 is bad, as it purports to extend the life of Ordinance No. IX of 1949 after the said Ordinance had already become dead.

facts.text: Petitioners contend Ordinance repugnant to Article 14 of Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Ordinance is bad as being repugnant to Art. 14 of the Constitution and The Ordinance also contravenes Art. 19 1 g of the Constitution in that it imposes unreasonable restrictions on the right of the petitioners to hold property.

facts.text: Preamble states growing tendency of landholders to eject tenants requiring protection for increasing foodgrain production

anchor.surface_text: The preamble to the Ordinance runs as follows Whereas with a view to putting a check on the growing tendency of landholders to eject or dispossess tenants from their holdings, and in the wider national interest of increasing the production of foodgrains, it is expedient to make provisions for the protection of tenants in Rajasthan from ejectment or dispossession from their holdings.

facts.text: Section 4 of Ordinance provides no tenant liable to ejectment while in force

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Ordinance provides So long as the Ordinance is in force in any area of Rajasthan, no tenant shall be liable to ejectment or dispossession from the whole or a part of his holding in such area on any ground whatsoever.

facts.text: Section 7 provides reinstatement for tenants in occupation on April 1, 1948 who were dispossessed later; extended by Amendment Act XVII of 1952 to later tenants

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 provides for reinstatement of tenants who had been in occupation on the first day of April, 1948, but had been subsequently dispossessed and by an Amendment Act No. XVII of 1952, this right was extended to tenants, who got into possession even after the first day of April.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 8, 1957 by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. February 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-These are petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by proprietors of lands in the State of Rajasthan, challenging the vires of The Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance, 1949,

arguments.claim: Court holds s.3 valid as conditional legislation authorising extension of duration

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion,, s. 3 of the Ordinance in so far as it authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of conditional legislation, and is, in consequence, intra vires.

arguments.claim: Distinguishes Jatindra Nath Gupta as there power included modification, inseparable from extension

arguments.claim: Follows Queen v Burah: power to decide time of operation is conditional legislation

anchor.surface_text: This is clear authority that a provision in a statute conferring a power on an outside authority to bring it into force at such time as it might, in its own discretion, determine, is conditional and not delegated legislation

arguments.claim: Extending duration where conditions persist is also conditional legislation, legislature having fixed content

anchor.surface_text: And it can make no difference in the character of a legislation as a conditional one that the legislature... confers a power on an outside authority to extend its operation for a further period if it is satisfied that the state of facts which called forth the legislation continues to subsist.

arguments.claim: Notification under s.3 derives validity from Ordinance, not requiring ongoing legislative power under Art.385

anchor.surface_text: The exercise of such a power is referable not to the legislative competence of the Rajpramukh but to Ordinance No- IX of 1949, and provided s. 3 is valid, the validity of the notification is co-extensive with that of the Ordinance.

holdings.text: s. 3 of the Ordinance in so far as it authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of conditional legislation, and is, in consequence, intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion,, s. 3 of the Ordinance in so far as it authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of conditional legislation, and is, in consequence, intra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature enacted complete law fixing content; authorizes executive to extend duration if conditions persist, per Queen v Burah and Delhi Laws Act; distinguishes Jatindra Nath Gupta as involving modification power.

holdings.text: A power to extend the life of an enactment can validly be conferred on an outside authority; disagrees with Jatindra Nath Gupta on this point.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that we are unable to agree with the statement of the law in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The, State of Bihar 2 that a power to extend the life of an enactment cannot validly be conferred on an outside authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure extension without modification is conditional legislation, no principled distinction from power to commence operation; legislature retains policy and content.

holdings.text: The notification dated June 20, 1953 is valid; objection overruled.

anchor.surface_text: This objection should accordingly be overruled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification exercises power conferred by valid s.3 of Ordinance, not independent legislation requiring Art.385 competence; validity co-extensive with Ordinance.

holdings.text: Impugned Ordinance not repugnant to Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the impugned Ordinance cannot be held to be bad under Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7 classification by April 1, 1948 date reasonable to effectuate preamble policy against ejectments; s.15 guided by preamble or severable.

holdings.text: Recitals in preamble not challengeable by parties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts cannot question legislative recitals of facts necessitating law; cites US precedent.

holdings.text: s.15 not violative of Art.14 as guided by preamble policy; even if bad, severable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble provides policy principle for discretion; added later, separable from core provisions.

holdings.text: Provisions not repugnant to Art.19(1)(f); obliging fixity of tenure to tillers reasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents arbitrary ejectment for food production interest; assures tenure to actual cultivator without preventing owner tillage per se; upheld analogous US rent control laws.

holdings.text: No need to decide validity of Act X of 1954 or limits of delegation as prior issues resolved in favor of validity.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, no need to discuss the matter further, as we are of opinion that the petitioners must fail in their contentions on the first two questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior holdings uphold Ordinance and notifications; moot.

holdings.text: Opinion reserved on permissible limits of delegation of legislative authority.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the question as to the permissible limits of delegation of legislative authority on which the judgments in In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 reveal a sharp conflict of opinion does not arise for consideration, and we reserve our opinion thereon.
